questions.prompt: 1. In BG 6.1, who is considered a true yogi according to Krishna?
choices: One who performs his prescribed duties without attachment to results
questions.feedback: A true yogi is one who performs duties without attachment, not one who abandons work.

questions.prompt: 2. In BG 6.2, what is described as both the means and the end of the yoga path?
questions.feedback: Renunciation of desire for results is both the means of yoga and its perfection.

questions.prompt: 3. In BG 6.3, when can a person be said to have attained yoga?
choices: When the mind is controlled and senses are under control
questions.feedback: Yoga is attained when one has subdued the mind and is free from all desires.

questions.prompt: 4. In BG 6.4, what uplifts a person, and what degrades them?
choices: The mind uplifts the self, and the mind degrades the self
questions.feedback: One's own mind can be either one's best friend or worst enemy; it lifts or degrades.

questions.prompt: 5. In BG 6.5, who is considered to have conquered the mind?
choices: One who has great military power
One whose mind is engaged in Krishna consciousness
One who is very learned in philosophy
questions.feedback: One who has subdued the mind is peaceful; such a one is dear to the Lord.

questions.prompt: 6. In BG 6.6, what is the first instruction for practicing meditation?
choices: Rise early and sit in a suitable place for practice
questions.feedback: A yogi must find a suitable place, purify the spot, and sit to meditate.

questions.prompt: 7. In BG 6.7, what should the yogi do while sitting steadily?
choices: Meditate on the Supersoul with the mind fixed
questions.feedback: The yogi should practice meditation with mind and senses controlled, fixed on the Supersoul.

questions.prompt: 8. In BG 6.8-9, what is the state of a successful yogi?
choices: Peaceful, equal-minded, desireless, and fixed in meditation
questions.feedback: A successful yogi is peaceful, mentally balanced, and fixed in meditation on Krishna.

questions.prompt: 9. In BG 6.10, how often should a yogi practice meditation?
choices: Always; constantly throughout the day and night
questions.feedback: A yogi should practice meditation constantly and never let the mind wander.

questions.prompt: 10. In BG 6.11-12, what is the proper place and posture for meditation?
choices: An elevated, clean place with a seat; body erect, eyes steady, and gaze fixed
questions.feedback: The yogi should sit in a clean place with proper posture and steady gaze for meditation.

questions.prompt: 11. In BG 6.13, what is the proper placement of the mind during meditation?
choices: On the objects of the senses
On the tip of the nose
questions.feedback: The yogi should focus the mind on the tip of the nose or at the center between the eyebrows.

questions.prompt: 12. In BG 6.14, what is the result of constant meditation?
questions.feedback: Steady meditation leads to transcendental bliss and freedom from fear and anxiety.

questions.prompt: 13. In BG 6.15, what is said about the yogi who is not disturbed by the senses?
choices: He is the greatest ascetic and is firmly established in yoga
He loses his sense of duty
questions.feedback: The yogi who is unmoved by pleasure or pain is firmly established and is the greatest ascetic.

questions.prompt: 14. In BG 6.16, what is the obstacle to yoga practice?
choices: Overeating; too little food; too much sleep; or too little sleep
questions.feedback: Irregular eating and sleeping habits, and indulgence, obstruct yoga progress.

questions.prompt: 15. In BG 6.17, who can be considered a true yogi?
choices: One who indulges in sense gratification
One who is moderate in eating, recreation, work, and sleep
questions.feedback: A yogi is one who is balanced and moderate in all activities.

questions.prompt: 16. In BG 6.18, when does the yogi become perfectly engaged in yoga?
choices: When the mind is controlled and freed from all material desires
questions.feedback: Perfect yoga is when the mind is fixed on Krishna and is free from all desires.

questions.prompt: 17. In BG 6.20-21, what is the ultimate goal of meditation?
choices: To achieve infinite transcendental happiness that is beyond the senses
questions.feedback: Through meditation, one attains unlimited transcendental joy beyond the material senses.

questions.prompt: 18. In BG 6.23, what is the meaning of yoga described in this chapter?
choices: Disconnection from the senses and mind
questions.feedback: Yoga is the disconnection of oneself from contact with worldly enjoyment.

questions.prompt: 19. In BG 6.24, what should the practitioner do when the mind becomes restless?
questions.feedback: When the mind wanders, one should patiently bring it back and continue meditation.

questions.prompt: 20. In BG 6.25-26, where is the mind placed in successful meditation?
questions.feedback: The successful yogi fixes the mind on the Supersoul and withdraws from all other engagements.

questions.prompt: 21. In BG 6.27, what is the result for the yogi who is absorbed in meditation?
choices: He attains the highest happiness and becomes free from material bondage
questions.feedback: The yogi engaged in meditation attains supreme happiness and liberation from material bondage.

questions.prompt: 22. In BG 6.29, what does the Lord consider about a yogi who is absorbed in Him?
choices: He is the greatest yogi and is always engaged in meditation on Him
He should engage in worldly affairs
questions.feedback: The Lord considers a yogi always thinking of Him to be the greatest yogi.

questions.prompt: 23. In BG 6.30, who is considered a true yogi by Krishna?
choices: One who sees the Supersoul in all beings and loves all equally
questions.feedback: A true yogi sees the Supersoul in all beings and loves all equally.

questions.prompt: 24. In BG 6.32 (purport), what is the relationship between a yogi and Krishna?
choices: Intimate and personal; the yogi considers Krishna his best friend
questions.feedback: A yogi's practice culminates in seeing Krishna as his intimate eternal friend.

questions.prompt: 25. In BG 6 (summary), what is the main purpose of this chapter's teachings?
choices: To guide meditation practice and union with the Supreme Consciousness
questions.feedback: Chapter 6 teaches the science and practice of meditation leading to union with Krishna consciousness.
